citations.title: Pharmacogenetics of anti-cancer drugs: State of the art and implementation - recommendations of the French National Network of Pharmacogenetics.
citations.summary: Individualized treatment is of special importance in oncology because the drugs used for chemotherapy have a very narrow therapeutic index. Pharmacogenetics may contribute substantially to clinical routine for optimizing cancer treatment to limit toxic effects while maintaining efficacy. This review presents the usefulness of pharmacogenetic tests for some key applications: dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPYD) genotyping for fluoropyrimidine (5-fluorouracil, capecitabine), UDP glucuronosylstransferase (UGT1A1) for irinotecan and thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) for thiopurine drugs. Depending on the level of evidence, the French National Network of Pharmacogenetics (RNPGx) has issued three levels of recommendations for these pharmacogenetic tests: essential, advisable, and potentially useful. Other applications, for which the level of evidence is still discussed, will be evoked in the final section of this review.

summaryMarkdown.html: The French National Network of Pharmacogenetics (Réseau national de pharmacogénétique (RNPGx)) states that there is no recommendation for genotyping CYP2D6 in all patients starting a tamoxifen regimen.

textMarkdown.html:
The French National Network of Pharmacogenetics (RNPGx) publication about the state of the art and clinical implementation — recommendations from the French National Network of Pharmacogenetics for anti-cancer drugs states:

Tamoxifen is indicated for the treatment of patients with breast cancer in an adjuvant or metastasis context. Tamoxifen requires bioactivation into the active metabolites 4-hydroxytamaxifen and endoxifen (N-demethyl-4- hydroxytamoxifen). CYP2D6, controlling the limiting step for the formation of endoxifen and 4-hydroxytamoxifen, is a highly polymorphous gene. There are three metabolizer phenotypes: extensive, intermediate and slow. Between 2005 and 2010, a certain number of studies demonstrated that patients with the intermediate or slow metabolizer phenotype had lower survival rates compared with patients with an extensive metabolizer phenotype due to less pronounced formation of the active metabolite [Article:19809024][Article:16361630]. Subsequently, highly conflicting results were published on this question [Article:22395643][Article:22395644][Article:24060820] such that to date there is no recommendation for genotyping CYP2D6 in all patients starting a tamoxifen regimen. While waiting for the results of prospective currently in process, this genotype could be potentially useful in certain specific cases (major adverse effects, no adverse effects).
